discussion.content: It's concerning accessibility, not storage capacity. The RAID 5 array is likely down and needs to be repaired.

comments.content: It's about understanding how RAID5 works vs regular storage. First the access was slowed because the array lost a disk. It limped on until another disk (probably the one picking up the slack) failed which caused the whole array to fail as RAID5 can only support 1 disk failure. If regular storage failed then files would have immediately been unavailable. If the drive was full then writing would be the issue, not drive failure. If fragmented then the access speed would suffer but it wouldn't cause failure.
This is not about a specific RAID type. The keywords here are access files "slower one week ago" and "unavailable today"

discussion.content: C is incorrect because if storage is full it does slow down access, but doesn't make it unavailable.

comments.content: why can't just be a dying drive who slow down and actually die a week later?
Yes, I believe the answer should be worded as check the hard disk instead of storage space.

discussion.content: RAID 5 IS storage space. If the RAID 5 is failing then storage space is becoming unavailable. In my experience, disks do not slowly fail. They fail completely all at once. If a RAID-5 disk failed then the data would remain available via the parity bits, but I-O response time would be significantly degraded - all at once - not gradually. However, OVERALL available storage space - other than the RAID-5 - would affect I-O response time if the disk space was completely maxed out. The I-O control would be constantly busy trying to find available space and failing.
Option A is correct. Remember one of the advantage of RAID 5 is to provide fast access to files. So it means one or more of the RAID disk was failing and finally went making the files not accessible.
I believe it would be RAID 5 array because this is a sign that one of the drives is failing or has failed and needs replacement.
Option C looks good to me too.

questions.question_text: An employee's mobile device no longer charges, and the employee believes the battery is bad. A technician tests the mobile device and finds it will charge on a wireless charging pad but not when it is connected to a charging cable. Other devices charge without issue when the cable is used. Which of the following should the technician perform FIRST to resolve the issue?

choices.A: Clean out the charging port on the device
choices.C: Issue a new charging cable to the employee
choices.D: Send the device for service and give the employee a loaner

discussion.content: I feel like you can skip the cable check on this one, the question states other devices can charge using the cable.

clean it out, then a new cable, then new battery, then send it in for service and give the employee a loaner. This is the order that I would go while troubleshooting for this question.
Remember the Keep It Simple, Stupid (KISS) method/principle. I would always check cabling for every problem that I run into.
Clean out the charging port on the device .correct
